Legal_Issue: Credibility, religious identity, risk assessment in refugee claim
Credibility_Assessment: Questioned due to inconsistencies in testimony, lack of corroboration, implausible travel details
Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence, documentary evidence on country conditions
Legal_Provision: Section 97 and Section 98 of IRPA (basis for refugee protection)
Basis_of_Claim: Persecution for attending an underground Christian church in China
Evaluation_Standard: Reasonableness standard for credibility and risk findings; correctness for legal errors
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credible evidence supporting Christian identity and persecution risk
Proceeding_Type: Refugee claim determination followed by judicial review
Regulation_Cited: IRPR Sections related to refugee eligibility and credibility
Legal_Standard: Standard of reasonableness applied to factual findings; correctness for legal interpretations
Application_Factor: Claimant's testimony, religious knowledge, travel history, country condition reports
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada
Decision_Review_Issue: Whether the Board’s decision was reasonable
Governing_Rule_or_Provision: IRPA s. 96-101, principles of procedural fairness, Charter considerations
Cause_of_Refusal: Doubt about genuine Christian identity, lack of credible evidence of persecution
Evidentiary_Issues: Inconsistencies in testimony, lack of independent corroboration
Procedural_Fairness: Assessed as upheld – applicant had opportunity to present case
Credibility_Issues: Inconsistent statements, implausible narrative, limited religious knowledge
Legal_Defense_or_Challenge: Challenge to reasonableness of Board's adverse credibility finding
Relevant_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Canadian jurisprudence on refugee claims
Procedural_Issue: Standard of review in administrative appeals
Omission_Type: Failure to provide sufficient corroborating evidence
